title: What is the most fun Beatles song to play on guitar? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve been doing an acoustic show with just myself on guitar and vocals, and another guy on vocals. So it’s 2 voices and 1 guitar. …and a looper sometimes. We’ve been doing a cover of “Here Comes the Sun.” It’s total hoot to play and always gets a semi-drunk audience up on their feet singing along with us. LOL

I’ve come around a little on this one: having played most of the Beatles’ songs on the guitar, I’ve come to the conclusion that their most fun song to play on guitar is a song I’ve previously not had much time for. The vast majority of Beatles songs have fairly simple but well-articulated guitar parts, and there’s not a lot of choosing between them. ‘A Hard Day’s Night’ is fun, but you need more than one guitar to get the effect of that big opening chord. ‘I Feel Fine’ is a test of stamina: try playing that riff note-perfect for the whole song, preferably while singing. It’s not easy. ‘All My Loving’ is regarded as just another early Beatles hit, but Lennon’s triplet guitar part is another real test of stamina. I love playing ‘Honey Pie’, with its little jazzy guitar solo, but it’s uncharacteristic of them. The reprise of ‘Sgt Pepper’ is fun, with those stabbing chords and the brisk pace, but it’s a very short song. ‘Strawberry Fields Forever’ is impossible to play along without going out of tune, because of the way the key of the song drifts slowly upwards, thanks to all the varispeeding that took place during production. But its guitar parts are in any case not the most fun things about it. ‘Ticket to Ride’ is enjoyable, but far more enjoyable if you play it the way Hüsker Dü played it: through a roaring fuzzbox. ‘I Am The Walrus’ doesn’t have a particularly distinguished guitar part, but it does cry out to be adapted into a solo guitar thing, with those lines in endless contrary motion. ‘Dig A Pony’ and ‘I’ve Got A Feeling’ are both good fun to play, as is ‘Let It Be’, where it’s a chance to play something epically tasteful during the solo. And ‘Get Back’ is just very groovy, especially for whoever gets to be Lennon and play those little C&W licks. But in the end, I think the most fun of all is ‘Helter Skelter’. Just get the tone right—not too much fuzz, just enough to roar—and that stabbing opening riff and the Hendrixoid chords are great fun. And the descending runs in A and E Mixolydian in the chorus are really, really fun. (‘Helter skelter!’ Dee-nee-nee-nah-nah-nah-now!) Bonus points if you have a whammy, or a whammy pedal, so at the end of the chorus, in the pause, you can hit a low E and then bennnnnnnnd it down slightly and up again. In fact, ‘Helter Skelter’ is arguably more fun to play than it is to listen to.
